Yoy, print book sales were: * up 18.5% in the first half of the year * down 2% in Q3 * up in October: * 2% in week ending Oct 9 * 2.7% in week ending Oct 16 * 7% in week ending Oct 23 * 12% in week ending Oct 30 So it looks likely that to date, print book sales are likely net substantially up for 2021 so far, with only 2 months to go. There do appear to be some supply chain issues, but there doesn't yet appear to be any shortage of print books.

I'm late to the party here but it looks like we're in August and 2021 sales are quite a bit higher than 2020 YTD sales were. So in order to see 2021 be lower than 2020 we'd have to see a significant slowdown and it looks like the slowdown is pretty gradual. https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/08/npd-sees-the-us-print-market-up-in-july-momentum-slowing/ Additionally many of the drivers (corona virus, political unrest, social justice issues) that made 2020 an outlier are still a factor this year.

With the pro's forecasting increased whole year sales in most scenarios it seems most likely to surpass 2020 even with the current slide. Check out @belikewater 's comments at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319722

Some people seem to be reacting to news about the first half of the year because articles have recently come out about these gains. However, since then, sales have sometimes been falling a bit compared to last year. E.g., https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87076-print-unit-sales-fell-1-7-last-week.html https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1310410 With projected declines in gains over the rest of the year, at least one analyst is arguing that 2021 will likely finish between 2% and 8% higher than 2020: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html So I think this forecast will end up being quite close. I do think the answer will be Yes, but I don't think it's a done deal.

Half year print sales ticked past 386M (1), which leaves 365M sales in Q3 and Q4 in order to resolve as a yes - target is 751M+1.

- Sales have increased 7 of the past 8 years according to https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/ - US book sales up 18.5% in the first half of 2021 compared to the first half of 2020, according to https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html. Based on https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/, seems like about 50k more books were sold during Q1 then Q2 was about equal - As @Skyreichel pointed out, according to https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html even if sales fall back to 2019 levels 2021 will still beat 2020 by 2%.

I am doubling my thought from 20% to 40% from some anecdotal data:

The question can be restated as "will 2021 book sales exceed 751 million in 2021?" With second quarter sales numbers in, the sales are already 387 million. To hit the target, second half sales would need to be 364 million or better. We know that sales won't keep up with last year in the second half (my strong assumption that we won't see another 424 million sales), but it seems unlikely that second half sales will fall below 2019 numbers (380 million). I expect third quarter numbers to be around 160 million. If it's above that, I'll move up. If it's lower, I'll need to reevaluate.
Yes, people have greater access to bookstores and ebooks don't cut it for most people.

2020 number was 751 million units. So far 205 million units were already sold in Q1 2021 (as opposed to 158 million copies in Q1 2020). https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/

Updating upwards. Sales are still up. 750.89M sold in 2020 (https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/ ) 205M sold in Q1 2021 (https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/ ) "This marks the highest volume of Q1 print sales since NPD BookScan began tracking sales in 2004" 205M / 750.89M = 0.27 => 27% of 2020 volume sold in 1st quarter. "Unit sales of print books rose a remarkable 29.2% in the first quarter of 2021 over the same period in 2020" https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86061-the-print-books-sales-surge-continues.html All the second quarter news articles I have seen have reported gains over the same week the previous year, so it appears likely that Q2 2021 print book sales will exceed Q2 2020 print book sales. So, it appears both Q1 and Q2 2021 data may exceed Q1 and Q2 data in 2020.

Per the linked article - using NPD Bookscan numbers - total print book sales are up 19% through 6/27/21 vs. the comparable 2020 period: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86816-print-sales-rose-6-4-at-the-end-of-june.html
Based on the first 6 months, we are op for the year. So it looks increasingly likely. Sales would have to drop now for a decline.

On the one hand, the last 5 years (2016-2020) we have a mean of 704M and Stdev of 30M print book sales per year. We know that Q1 2021 had 205M units sold, so we might extrapolate (if this continues) that this year will have 820M sales. (I couldn't find any info of the seasonality of book sales). This Q1 indicator tells me it is more likely than not that 2021 sales will exceed 2020 sales, but I cannot say by exactly how much. However, this does not take into account the fact that the US is opening up with many states having few or no restrictions, and so this Q1 figure might be an artifact of a world still affected by covid (but this is changing rapidly).

Q1 2020 was pre-pandemic, so the Q1 to Q1 numbers are very inflated. The rest of the year is competing against the high-water marks from COVID sales. It will be interesting to see the Q2 numbers to get a better gauge of where things are. For now, I'm assuming we will see decreased YoY sales in the latter half of the year and that will bring the annual numbers below last year.
The link found by @jayb ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1298106 ) shows that near the midpoint of the year, we're up nearly 20% YoY. What would cause us to be down a greater amount in H2?
Too early to tell but sales seem strong YOY so far in 2021.

I expect that the recent surge in 2020 will not continue with the ending of the pandemic. So there is a modest chance of the trend continuing, I think.
2020 was a covid peak year - 2021 is likely to be a return to the mean also: rise of digital books versus print will dampen the print sale, especially when people can travel again

Maybe people's reading habits will continue post-lockdown...lots of people will have used lockdown to write books and there might be a new J K Rowling among the new writers which could account for a big difference... hmm... probably not too likely on that one... airports reopening mean more sold there... thinking about it though, people won't have as much time to read and maybe not finished all the books they bought last year so maybe a slight decrease...word of mouth on ones they have read might generate some traction... or a big summer blockbuster though might tip it... or maybe people have been reading more widely so the whole water level rises.... tricky to call at this stage....probably not on balance....

Sales were at their highest because people were stuck at home often. Soon, they will not be. Online book sales will improve. Online libraries will increase in prevalence and stock. I do not see print books' advantage in the coming year.
https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/

The pandemic clearly affected book sales, and it should have a reduced effect this year, as vaccine rollout gradually returns normalcy to the U.S. Book sales have shown natural growth hovering around 2% per year, which, combined with sales from early this year, might overcome 2020, but I have my doubts. I initially planned on 5%, but things are pretty uncertain right now, so I'll start with 10.

The growth in the sale of print books in 2020 seems largely due to the pandemic (as stated in articles written about the NPD article linked in the question, source 1). Further, NPD statistics seem to have been led by juvenile fiction, juvenile non-fiction, and adult non-fiction in real terms. However, the growth in adult categories of books was much smaller than juvenile categories in percentage terms. Extrapolating the overall intent of many book purchases seems to be to provide juveniles with something to occupy their time when no longer in school in person and to provide an outlet for adults to better themselves during the pandemic outside of work. If in-person work and school returns across the US in 2021 the overall sales of juvenile books and adult non-fiction will probably not be as robust as in 2020. This does not look likely broadly across the US until the fall. That means three quarters which will probably robust sales of print books at a minimum, which was also the case in 2020 as only three quarters saw strong print book sales in 2020. Therefore, book sales will probably continue to be strong, as was seen in the first quarter of 2021 (source 2).

Adding in analysis from @Vincentvd - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1275393. Q1 Sales of 205M books means that we have 546M remaining units required to hit the 751M. This requires an average of 182M books sold for Q2, Q3, and Q4. While the strong sales number was worth a point, Q1 2021 was very similar to Q4 of 2020 from a lifestyle perspective.

I appreciate this analysis from @higg1508 for giving a solid analysis - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1275603. I believe a lot of this was due to lockdowns and people running out of things to do at home. There are other reasons cited in the articles are also important to consider - home schooling and kids indoors.

I anticipate the trend is largely due to lockdowns etc - while less significant (one hopes) in 2021 than 2021, I imagine some of the features of this has/will continue in 2021 - working from home etc (and there must be some chance of a resurgence of covid particularly variants due to irresponsibility as lockdowns are lifted). Lack of commuting may well continue which reduces the comparative demand for audio books/kindle versus real books. Books coming to attention of people during the last year are likely to have attention reinforced as people socialise and discuss in real life, and now can buy them on an impulse buy from real stores. This has a real chance of maintaining relatively high print book sales.
2020 had multiple factors propelling sales, including the Election and forced time at home. Unlikely to be repeated in 2021.

Looking at the categories where sales were good in 2020 and the top sellers I don’t think this year will pass last year. Why: 1) a lot of juvenile non fiction was sold. I translate this as a lot of home schooling textbooks and help 2) a lot of the fiction books both adult and juvenile are also likely related to being furloughed, unemployed, or stuck as home during COVID 3) election 2020. A lot of high profile trump books that were part of the election craziness. That isn’t going to happen this year.

2020 started slow in Q1 and Q2 (1) but was probably saves by Covid and the subsequent lockdowns and other measures in Q3 and 4. The ellection also seems to have had some impact with more people buying political books. (2). Q1 2021 saw the growth from Q4 2020 continue (3) Whats going to be interesting is how long the Covid measures will stay in place and what will happen with books sales when they are scaled back. My expectation is that books sales will see little growth when measure are lifted and people start going out. When this will happen will be a big influence on book sales growth. If life returns to normal at the start of Q3 or earlier books sales will likely not be greater than 2020. If measures are lifted in Q3 there is a change book sales will increase. Given the current vaccination drive 70% vaccination rate should be achieved at the end of august. (4) Also interesting to see is how reading habits have changed. Juvenile books where the top performers of 2020, if a lot of kids can keep the reading habit this could cause a surprise sales lift even when restrictions are lifted.

Take out the political gibberish books driven by an ambiance of lackadaisical group thinking and the reduction in factual substance, you get a year of doubt, thus flat sales at best. We might start to see a boom on Covid related know-it-all-books, that might help a little, but not enough. To get people to read while enjoyin the new covid time with friends is going to be tricky and many school books are going digital in many cases after the at-home experience. My guess is that the ratio is coming down at espectacular speed to be a lower printing year, the price of pulp is rising costs. Cost contaiments in place in an industry that makes money in less than .5% of the books plublished are going to be a trend. Uncle Sam cannot keep buying junk indefinitely, or can he?

The asking rate isnt that high for the next 9months as Q1 sales were strong Some rough calculations (for calculating asking rate to achieve 751mn sales in 2021) and links(for sources given in the sheet)

There was so many catalysts in 2020 for the increase, as mentioned many places, home schooling, online book clubs, BLM and social issues. Just anecdotal but here the libraries were on and off closed which led to me purchasing more books as well. But there may yet be catalysts in 2021, some new TV or movie series might spur on massive book sales of a series or even entire genre. I also think everyone who is travelling anywhere will have to buy an entire brand new book rather than a used or borrow one, because half the businesses wont exist anymore, but this might be a negligible amount compared to the total.
If you look at historical sales, print has been growing at a steady 3% since 2012. (https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/)

I noticed the point about unit sales YoY, so I'm setting my probability to slightly above the consensus and revisiting in a week. My original view was we might be above 2019 but less than last year, but it could end up being a close finish given the headstart for 2021.

I can't see it happening. With the pandemic happening, the resulting price of lumber has exploded. The cost of procuring materials for books has to be related to the supply of the wood somehow... not sure yet, but to me if wood is more expensive, that cost is going to be passed on to the consumer. So, even if there are more produced, costs could prove prohibitive in a relative sense of book purchasing. Want to look more in to the correlation as related to physical book production...
I would expect regression to the mean after a best-in-a-decade result quite likely driven by COVID and likely to recede as restrictions are relaxed.
I've never read a book and can't imagine reading one now.
More books published, but Less time for reading

I doubt it. Sales went way up because of the pandemic. Now, people want to go ***out***. Many restrictions are likely to be lifted once everyone who wants a vaccine has had one (e.g., as in New York), and I don't think books are going to be on quite as many people's minds.

As pointed out by others here: "Unit sales of all print books were up 26% through May 1 compared to the same period in 2020." (Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86268-print-units-rose-12-4-last-week.html)
First quarter sales were up a lot this year, which provides a base.
Last year appears to have been an anomaly, but perhaps the habit has been formed and the new trend will continue.
covid is going away and so are lockdowns
